data.text: Bike Touring with Hypertension and Anxiety Conditions
Big and personal question...anyone tour with hypertension and anxiety conditions? Does it go well for you? I'm curious to hear from you?

I found relief from my anxiety big time ! I think it was the simplification of life. Wake up ,eat peddle, eat more, peddle , sleep. After a week or so it becomes a very comfortable rhythm. You should go for it !
data.author: John Sperline

data.text: That was the comfort I found in touring, too. Life was reduced to survival and what I carried on two wheels, and neither was such a burden. I also found that it helped me process my thoughts when I had life stuff to think about. By the end of a short tour, I'd have an answer for whatever I was going over in my head, or my feelings about it would be settled.
data.author: Bradley Gentry

data.text: I second this!
data.author: Nicola Jackson

data.text: Sure! Check and check! Touring keeps me the calmest I ever am. I take my meds, keep hydrated, but a lot of my symptoms melt away on a tour.
data.author: Jen Klaudinyi

data.text: The bike cured all my deseases, mentally and physically üòÅ
data.author: Fast Fuso

data.text: I found the physical output really helps. I started jogging at the suggestion of my dad, when my daily cycling to work wasn't helping. It started a year long training and doing some triathlons. I wasn't competitive, I just did them as a social thing. In the end it allowed me to get a better handle on the relation between my physical exertion and my mental wellbeing. Even today when some physical things don't allow for cycling or jog, if I've been inside and feeling down like today, I'll plan to stop at a couple antique malls and walk every aisle tomorrow. It's the 2nd of 3-4 days of rain...
data.author: Whit Elfner

data.text: My wife has PTSD an we did a 12,000 mile tour around the perimeter of the USA. One of the themes of her book Allegiance to Winds and Waters is about fears and how we as individuals and a society construct false narratives to relieve our anxiety but in the long run exasperate it.
data.author: David Winkler-Morey

data.text: I think it can be fine. Although one time I had a panic attack at the start of a week long tour and postponed the trip so I guess you need flexibility. I do much better now, I wish you well on your journey...
data.author: David Baker-Yuill

data.text: I do suffer from anxiety and panic attacks (PTSD). I started my long distance tour with my partner last Aug. I had one panic attack in 7.5 months only - that was quite at the beginning. I actually did not think about this condition anymore. Now I am back home (Germany) since a week and The last three days I barely slept because my heart keeps rushing from anxiety again. Thanks God we are only here for a "break" and head off again in a few weeks!
data.author: Iris Mueller

data.text: It's curious really, If I travel to unknown places, and not very city areas, my anxiety is almost non-existent, but in cities, or returning same routes, my anxiety tends to perk up a bit. In that case, I take detours if possible
data.author: Cat C Carlson

data.text: Anxiety here. There are many tours I haven't done because I was unable to do the first step... well, everything was planned and then I just didn't, because what if *gestures vaguely at everything* The ones I did were awesome, tho (not that anxiety didn't show its ugly face during the tour, telling me all the things that could go wrong, just to make me quit and then call me a failure)
data.author: Uli Fiedler

data.text: Thanks for sharing. Inspired me to try to heal myself through cycling.
data.author: Shirley Anne

data.text: Best thing you can do
data.author: Jeff Neumann

data.text: I think it‚Äôs ‚Äònormal‚Äô to feel anxious before a big trip . The regular daily exercise is going to be great for blood pressure . I always remind myself that the two most useless emotions are guilt and worry . I did 3 months solo in Canada in 2017. I will never regret that decision.
data.author: Micaela Elphick

data.text: I have a list a mile long and travel with a cpap. If I‚Äôm at home I still hurt mentally and physically at least riding I keep myself busy with healthy distractions. 22 a day unacceptable and I will not give in to the war within
data.author: Joseph Delagarza

data.text: On the first day of a tour, I often bitterly ask myself why on earth am I doing this to myself? But as the rhythm of the ride develops in the course of that first day, the question disappears. I think it's entirely natural and normal to feel some trepidation at the beginning of a difficult undertaking. The willingness to go forward despite that provides dividends in self-confidence.
data.author: Mark R. Stewart

data.text: I think getting out the door is the hardest part. Especially, riding rail trails, I like the rhythm of the day. I know what I‚Äôm going to‚Ä¶ride my bike. ‚Äú give me the courage to take the first step‚Äù
data.author: Paula Termini

data.text: Not to any such conditions, but my job has induced lot of unnecessary anxiety in me. So I started cycling to office regularly, using longer routes. It calmed me down a lot. My control on situation improved immensely. I suggest that instead of going one big tour, you should consistently go on small tours. Your body will respond and guide you for more.
data.author: Balraj Singh

data.text: I have recently lost my home due to greedy landlords converting to yet another AirB&B*. Given 30 days to vacate (it‚Äôs still full-on winter here in Alaska and the rental market is expensive and very tight), I‚Äôve been in a near constant state of panic since March 1, so much so that I also crashed my car. Ahhh. So now I‚Äôm riding my bike to work every day. At 5:15 am I have the city trails to myself and my ride is extremely therapeutic, I have calmed down a lot, and I feel better about life in general. I suppose this couldn‚Äôt have happened to a better person because my big Salsa has massive, studded tires and giant panniers and the bike paths covered in sloping, glaciated ice, running water, and ice chunk-filled potholes are no big deal. I also own a bus, soon to be outfitted with a big bike rack. If I still can‚Äôt find a safe, quiet, affordable place to live soon, I‚Äôll move into the hospital parking lot, quit my job in August, and go on a long bicycle tour instead. Bicycling of any distance or effort is scientifically proven to reduce hypertension and anxiety! (*And please, if you would, don‚Äôt patronize AirB&B. This trend is slowly destroying communities all over America.)
data.author: Catherine Ann

data.text: I do .... cycling actually helps with both
data.author: Stuart Mather

data.text: My anxiety is terrible. Touring helps. It brings a sense of freedom etc. I‚Äôm happiest on the road.
data.author: Ty Dawley

data.text: So happy to see the consensus above! Yes I suffer from anxiety too, and touring is a very safe place for me, wherever I am. I'm probably more able to cope with wild camping alone that in a lot of social situations üòÑ In what ways does your anxiety impact you?
data.author: Ruth Burgess

data.text: I do much better on the bicycle than any other time or place
data.author: Chaya Kostelicki AU

data.text: One of the drivers of general anxiety is underestimating your ability to cope when things go wrong and avoiding risky situations for fear of not coping. When going on a cycle trip things inevitably don't go entirely to plan but then some how you manage to cope which increases your belief in your ability to cope. Hence over time the anxiety decreases and enjoyment increases. In addition when things go wrong often others will come to your aid which challenges beliefs about the world being a scary place. Usually the worst that happens is you have to abandon the trip and return home. Then its a learning opportunity. Also when cycling your focus of attention shifts form "internal" to "external" which reduces any unhelpful internal dialogue.So for Anxiety you need CBT (constant bicycle therapy) Ps my job is a CBT therapist..the other sort.
data.author: Angie Dave

data.text: I love this, thank you!
data.author: Ruth Burgess

data.text: While ramping up for my cross country tour a couple years ago, I cut back on my Atenolol and Lisinopril while watching my BP. My BP was stable without them by the time I left so I carried a few doses with me for just-in-case. After I got back, injury and a different work schedule curtailed my riding and my BP started going back up so I started taking them again.
data.author: Sam Morris

data.text: I sit at home with hypertension and anxiety. Once I get on the bike, I relax.
data.author: Robert Prunella

data.text: Does anyone get muscle cramps from taking lisinopril?
data.author: Bruce Strassel

data.text: when I was taking it I got dehydrated easily. Could be the reason for cramps.
data.author: Glenn Tatum

data.text: ....if your prone to muscle cramps from cycling..I now have found taking magnesium has helped!
data.author: Bruce Strassel

data.text: yeah. I take either magnesium at night or mix a hot CALM tea drink.
data.author: Glenn Tatum

data.text:

data.author: Glenn Tatum

data.text: ....tks, that's a great product actually!
data.author: Bruce Strassel
